myhabalixyp wrote:

>As we know, NEAT gets a abnormity topology structure of a ANN for a 
>special function not similar with the traditional BP networks. Since 
>the traditional BP networks are constructed with clear layers.
>
Firstly I don't think networks *have* to be arranged in layers for 
back-propagation to work, it's just traditional and easy to do. In fact 
I'm not sure if they even have to be feedforward. As such it would be 
entirely feasible to use something like NEAT to search topolgies and 
then use back-prop to find connection weights.

> Now I'm 
>puzzled that it seems more complex for a abnormity topology structure 
>network to workout the output of a input although it has less nodes and 
>connections.It takes more memory and longer time.
>
I'm not sure I follow. Do you mean the amount of CPU time requried to 
propagate a signal from the input to an output?

> Although the networks 
>with layers have more "complex" topology, them have regular algorithm 
>and can workout a output more quickly with less memory. What benefit do 
>the abnormity topology structure networks bring to us? Only becaues 
>they are "simpler" only when we see them with our eyes?
>  
>
The benefit is that they represent the complete set of possible 
topolgies. Layered feed forward networks are just a sub-set of the 
possible topologies and as such are such are incapable of performing 
some tasks. I think I see your point though, one argument for using NEAT 
is to find compact topologies, but in searching for a compact topology 
we actually can end up with a lot of redundant structure. Now if you 
know approximately the structure required to solve a given problem then 
it will be more efficient to constrain the toplogy search somehow, which 
might be an intersting research angle. In the general case though we 
have no idea what topology is required (competetive co-evolution 
experiments for example) and so the open ended-ness of NEAT makes sense.

Colin.
